title: What will the Federal Open Market Committee decide to do with respect to the federal funds rate at its scheduled December 2017 meeting?
preds:
U.S. producer prices rose in November as gasoline prices surged and the cost of other goods increased, leading to the largest annual gain in nearly six years. The fairly strong report from the Labor Department on Tuesday suggested a broad acceleration in wholesale price pressures, which could assuage concerns among some Federal Reserve officials over persistently low inflation. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-inflation/u-s-producer-prices-rise-strongly-point-to-firming-inflation-idUSKBN1E61O5?feedType=RSS&feedName=newsOne Central banks raise rates in response to higher inflation.

With the unemployment near 4%, the USD sliding, crude oil over $60/barrel, S & P 500 at all time highs and a potential tax cut that will explode the US budgetary deficit, if the Fed does not raise rates in December, what could they be waiting for? It seems everything is pointing them in one direction.

http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html 100-125	0.0%	
125-150	91.5%	
150-175	8.5%	
* Current data as of 20 Nov 2017 12:38:08 CT
Shifting a little higher given financial rumors and general consensus.
Today CPI number consistant with inflation picking up, albeit very gradually. Fed likely to follow course and hike.
The scuttlebutt has shifted from hold to raise of late, so we'll see.  I'm still not sure about this, but nobody should care about that.
The projection is based on the current implied Fed Funds probability of a hike at the December meeting.

The market is pretty clear on a consensus at the moment. There will most likely be a raise due to better than expected unemployment, GDP growth numbers, and inflation. Barring a major economic disaster in the next few weeks, a raise seems likely.
With unemployment continually dropping and economic performance solid, the anticipated federal funds rate has a high probability of occuring at this point.
Philly Fed President Harker, a voting member on the FOMC, said he expects a hike in December.
Based on current economic growth and employment numbers

Surely the Recent US jobs data (261,000 jobs created & unemployment fown to 4.1%), and surging crude oil prices have all but sealed the deal, right? If not, I am not sure what the Fed would be waiting for.

Since the Federal reserve has begun raising rates in 2015, they have done so in December. (Dec '15, & '16) December is a good time to raise rates because we are at the end of the year and can easily compare the current year to previous forecasts, as well as plainly see the health of the economy throughout the year.  They have risen rates twice in 2017. Many Federal Reserve members have indicated that a third increase this year is possible. The Fed's dot plot for 2017 shows a range between 1.25%-1.50%, which would require a rate hike to achieve that range, because the current the Federal Funds rate is 1%-1.25%. As of this writing the Federal Funds rate has been trading at 1.16%. 2017 actuals have exceeded the Fed's expectations in terms of GDP growth. Additionally, the unemployment rate is at 4.1%, which is below their expectations for 2017. And inflation will most likely settle within or come slightly short of the Fed's expectations. These 3 primary metrics monitored by the fed increase the likelihood of a rate increase in December.  Reasons not to raise rates include: Janet Yellen is generally dovish. The federal reserve officials are generally very ambiguous with their thinking. So it's very challenging to determine what they will do based on newly available data. However, given the Fed's dot plot expectations for 2017, and where they want to go in December, a rate increase is palatable.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-fed-markets-analysis/powell-for-federal-reserve-chair-could-support-stocks-bull-market-idUSKBN1D20EY
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-fed/trump-expected-to-name-powell-as-next-federal-reserve-chair-on-thursday-idUSKBN1D15Z8
The name of the game is now apparently WWJD (What Would Janet Do?)  She had been talking up a smallish raise for several weeks, but that notion has abated some of late.  If the New Kid is confirmed by the December meeting, which I think unlikely, we may see a raise.   If not, I think they'll hold off even on a small bump.  I am very likely wrong about all or most of this. @Raahul_Kumar, I am flattered by your confidence, but if I were me I might not listen to me.  So far nobody is buying this argument except the two of us.  One could rightly be nervous on that score.
as per Fed Fund futures implied probabilities

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed/fed-set-to-hold-rates-steady-ahead-of-trumps-leadership-decision-idUSKBN1D13JT
They say they'll be holding.  Probably should believe them, even though that wasn't the rap a couple of weeks ago.
They will decide to raise rates with or without signs of inflation.  Stock market currently high and rising while inflation is showing signs of increasing.

-The major indices look like they will finish the year stronger than expected. 
-The lower rates have distorted the markets to certain extremes, causing nervousness and riskier behavior. By the Fed signaling a gradual raise in rate the investor community could start moving cash back to fixed incomes (and slowly deflate certain apparent bubbles like say cryptos).
The core inflation rate has been below the fed's target rate for six months now. That isn't something I would focus on, but I know it's something the fed looks at.
Allow for possibility of surprising news, but raise is most likely.
Recent meeting had a cautious tone

WSJ economist survey says 95% of those surveyed think a rate hike will happen in December. Since at least 2009, it seems there has been some sort of societal pressure to raise rates back to "normal" levels so I discounted it for that.
The fed seems on track to raise rates according to what I am reading.

As long as there isn't enough inflation the Federal Open Market Committee won't raise the federal funds rate.
The Federal Open Market Committee won't decrease the federal funds rate to less than 0-0.25 because they don't want to have a negative federal funds rate.

Upping my forecast on the following out yesterday from Reuters.  "Following the U.S. jobs data, the rate futures market has priced in a more than 90 percent chance of a Fed tightening in December, according to CME's FedWatch." CME FedWatch:  http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/

1. The FED Chair is to be elected. So we dont know who will be making decision
2. Recent economic factors are acceptable but not great (employment, GDP growth etc.), there are some  data missing expectations.
3. I leave 5% for lowering of interest just in case something bad happens in between now and Xmas (like a massive financial crisis)
One more rise was how commentators summed up the minutes of the latest FED meeting. More input could be gained by looking at what the market is pricing in and interpreting the dot chart.
purely based on fed fund pricing at the moment

Pushing up my forecast based on a few articles that point towards a march to a rate hike: Fed expected to downplay weak data:
http://economistsview.typepad.com/economistsview/2017/10/fed-poised-to-downplay-weak-data.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+EconomistsView+%28Economist%27s+View%29 Jannet yellen's statement that inflation weakness is temporary
http://economistsview.typepad.com/economistsview/2017/09/inflation-weakness-is-temporary.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+EconomistsView+%28Economist%27s+View%29 Any serious slowdown would require Fed to hold off on a rate adjustment, but short of that there is a strong desire to build up a rate buffer to have some leverage when the next cycle comes around.

https://www.cvent.com/c/express/27506cea-0bdc-4262-945a-47f21f183c4b I was able to attend this event today with Robert Kaplan (President of the Dallas Fed branch). He is a current voting member for the FOMC. The question that we are forecasting was asked. He was able to give his opinion... Upon making his decision he is looking for indicators to check mark if he will maintain/raise rates. They are full employment (using U6 unemployment rate), inflation objectives, business have less pricing pressures, inflation trends accelerating. He checked marked the full employment and inflation objectives. He was vague on the other two topics. He wants to see a gradual and slow pace increase. The cyclical vs the structural mechanics of economics play an important role. He stated he will be closely looking at the data over the next 2 months.  A great process that keeps him fluid within the economy is that he calls at least 30 CEO's (did not state the industries) per month to see how the economy is churning. He lastly saw that over the next few years that GDP was likely to lower based on the current aging demographic for the US.  One stat he said that I found interesting is 70% of the trade between Mexico and the US were intermediate goods. As one of my graduate school economics teachers (was on Regan's economic council) says "We need Mexico as much as Mexico needs us".

pce near or at 2%
rates will go up in either  Oct, November, Dec.
 October looks possible
Nov.   December ?
well last year December
i discard 10  4 major hurricanes adn Xmas starts for retail now 
i discard 11 just before  xmas
by December this .25 fed funds increase will be baked in

They start (at least they try) to reduce federal funds in general. To do so it must be more attractive. And there is a big misbalance in the Money Market. Which results in misallocation of liquid assets.

Fed funds market pricing in 70% chance, historically they have a strong correlation with the correct outcome;
http://www.marketwatch.com/story/yellen-says-fed-should-be-wary-of-raising-rates-too-gradually-2017-09-26 Prediction adjusted slightly for recency bias and the 3 month time period for possible fluctuations
The Honourable Chair continues to make noises like this is what the Fed will do.  In the ordinary course of events, one is better off in this matter to heed what she says.

I think the Fed are likely to
Put off further hikes til 2018

Returns on two and five year treasuries are already climbing in anticipation of the FED unloading 10 billion dollars a month worth of treasuries on the market. When they actually start doing that returns will have to rise even more in order to attract buyers. This means that Returns on related and competing products will rise as well. The fed may as well raise the federal funds rate because rates are going to effectively rise on their own anyway. I am skeptical that the market will be able to handle all of this, but the FED can either change their mind and reverse their decision to unwind their balance sheet or they can double down and raise rates in December. http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-09-27/treasury-sells-5y-paper-highest-yield-march
Coming in at consensus. They will probably raise rate, as the last two increases didn't harm markets. Will move accordingly when Fed begins to hint at what it intends.
For sure a lower rate is not desired. Although a rise would be preferred, economic developments dictate a maintaining of current rates.

12/16 members are already signaling support for a rise in December. Employment numbers will continue worrying members that inflation may bubble up if they don't lower rates enough. On the other hand, balance sheet shrinking could be seen as a defacto rate adjustment and could impact inflation negatively, leading to a maintain decision in December. Finally, an always small chance of a black swan event that would require a quick decision to inject liquidity by lowering rates.

Speculation after the FED meeting:
Inflation is low, doesn't really merit a rate rise.  Might the anticipated FED rate raise be targeted at high credit, and market levels?

My base rate is that of the futures market, which currently indicates a 72% probability of a raise and I'm adjusting upward slightly with a view that European and QT will likely impact debt markets more than markets anticipate.

Starting with market implied probabilities given here:
http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html . Given there is currently about a 70% chance that Yellen will not remain chairwomen, increasing rates as a consequence of the economy being in a good place might be a nice way to go out - bumping 3 points up.
A slight delay in the next hike doesn't seem like a extremely unlikely scenario.

The Fed forward guidance all year has focused on three hikes and they have been consistent so far, so no reason to believe they won't follow-up on the promise. The data would have to deteriorate significantly for them to consider altering course, as their view seems to be very much medium-term, instead of short.
Rise would be counter-productive for the Economy.

Given the health of the US economy and low unemployment I think inflation starts to pick up at some point this year. Given that there wasn't a September rate increase I think that increases the odds of a December increase.

While the FOMC has indicated that it will maintain current interest rates at its meeting this week, given inflation, hurricanes, and other metrics, it will most likely (currently at a .50 probability) that it could increase interest rates at the December meeting.  It should however be noted that there is a possibility that the prospect of an increase could be dampened by the scope and depth of e recovery in southern states; regarding inflation, it is well within in expected range and their are currently no indications that this will change.
